## Abstract.text:
## Abstract

Believable proxies of human behavior can empower interactive applications ranging from immersive environments to rehearsal spaces for interpersonal communication to prototyping tools. In this paper, we introduce generative agents—computational software agents that simulate believable human behavior. Generative agents wake up, cook breakfast, and head to work; artists paint, while authors write; they form opinions, notice each other, and initiate conversations; they remember and reflect on days past as they plan the next day. To enable generative agents, we describe an architecture that extends a large language model to store a complete record of the agent's experiences using natural language, synthesize those memories over time into higher-level reflections, and retrieve them dynamically to plan behavior. We instantiate generative agents to populate an interactive sandbox environment inspired by The Sims, where end users can interact with a small town of twenty five agents using natural language. In an evaluation, these generative agents produce believable individual and emergent social behaviors: for example, starting with only a single user-specified notion that one agent wants to throw a Valentine's Day party, the agents autonomously spread invitations to the party over the next two days, make new acquaintances, ask each other out on dates to the party, and coordinate to show up for the party together at the right time. We demonstrate through ablation that the components of our agent architecture—observation, planning, and reflection—each contribute critically to the believability of agent behavior. By fusing large language models with computational, interactive agents, this work introduces architectural and interaction patterns for enabling believable simulations of human behavior.

## 1 Introduction.text:
## 1 Introduction

How might we craft an interactive artificial society that reflects believable human behavior? From sandbox games such as The Sims to applications such as cognitive models [21] and virtual environments [9, 58], for over four decades researchers and practitioners have envisioned computational agents that can serve as believable proxies of human behavior. In these visions, computationally powered agents act consistently with their past experiences and react believably to their environments. Such simulations of human behavior could populate virtual spaces and communities with realistic social phenomena [26, 79], train people how to handle rare yet difficult interpersonal situations [43, 51, 93], test social science theories [11, 45], craft model human processors for theory and usability testing [21, 38, 50], power ubiquitous computing applications [30] and social robots [9, 13], and underpin non-playable game characters [58, 84] that can navigate complex human relationships in an open world.

However, the space of human behavior is vast and complex [84, 108]. Despite striking progress in large language models [17] that can simulate believable human behavior at a single time point [38, 79], fully general agents that ensure long-term coherence would be better suited by architectures that manage constantly-growing memories as new interactions, conflicts, and events arise and fade over time, while handling cascading social dynamics that unfold between multiple agents. Success requires an approach that can retrieve relevant events and interactions over a long period, reflect on those memories to generalize and draw higher-level inferences, and apply that reasoning to create *plans and reactions* that both make sense in the moment and in the longer-term arc of the agent's behavior.

In this paper, we introduce *generative agents*—agents that draw on generative models to simulate believable human behavior—and demonstrate that they produce believable simulacra of both individual and emergent group behavior. Generative agents draw a wide variety of inferences about themselves, other agents, and their environment; they create daily plans that reflect their characteristics and experiences, act out those plans, react, and re-plan when appropriate; they respond when the end user changes their environment or commands them in natural language. For instance, generative agents turn off the stove when they see that their breakfast is burning, wait outside the bathroom if it is occupied, and stop to chat when they meet another agent they want to talk to.

A society full of generative agents is marked by emergent social dynamics where new relationships are formed, information diffuses, and coordination arises across agents.

To enable generative agents, we describe an agent architecture that stores, synthesizes, and applies relevant memories to generate believable behavior using a large language model. Our architecture comprises three main components. The first is the *memory stream*, a long-term memory module that records, in natural language, a comprehensive list of the agent's experiences. The retrieval model combines relevance, recency, and importance to surface the records that are needed to inform the agent's moment-to-moment behavior.

The second is *reflection*, which synthesizes memories into higher-level inferences over time, enabling the agent to draw conclusions about itself and others to better guide its behavior. The third is planning, which translates those conclusions and the current environment into high-level action plans and then recursively into detailed behaviors for action and reaction. These reflections and plans are fed back into the memory stream to influence the agent's future behavior.

This architecture suggests applications in multiple domains, from role-play and social prototyping, to virtual worlds and games. In social role-play scenarios (e.g. interview preparation), a user could safely rehearse difficult, conflict-laden conversations. When prototyping social platforms, a designer could go beyond temporary personas to prototype dynamic, complex interactions that unfold over time. For the purposes of this paper, we focus on the ability to create a small, interactive society of agents inspired by games such as The Sims.1 By connecting our architecture to the ChatGPT large language model [76], we manifest a small society of twenty five agents in a game environment. End users can observe and interact with these agents. If an end user or developer wanted the town to host an in-game Valentine's Day party, for example, traditional game environments would require scripting tens of characters' behavior manually. We demonstrate that, with generative agents, it is sufficient to simply tell one agent that she wants to throw a party. Despite many potential points of failure—the party planner must remember to tell other agents about the party, attendees must remember the invitation, those who remember must decide to actually show up, and other possible points of failure—agents in our environment succeed. They spread the word about the party and then show up, with one agent even asking another agent on a date to the party, all from this single user-generated seed suggestion.

We conducted two evaluations of generative agents: a controlled evaluation to test whether the agents produce believable individual behaviors in isolation, and an end-to-end evaluation where the generative agents interacted with each other in open-ended ways over two days of game time to understand their stability and emergent social behaviors. In the technical evaluation, we leverage a methodological opportunity to evaluate an agent's knowledge and behavior by "interviewing" it in natural language to probe agents' ability to stay in character, remember, plan, react, and reflect accurately. We compared several ablations that limit agents' access to memory, reflection, and planning. We observe that each of these components is critical to strong performance across these interview tasks. Across the technical and the end-to-end evaluation, the most common errors arose when the agent failed to retrieve relevant memories, fabricated embellishments to the agent's memory, or inherited overly formal speech or behavior from the language model.

In sum, this paper provides the following contributions:

- *Generative agents*, believable simulacra of human behavior that are dynamically conditioned on agents' changing experiences and environment.

- A novel architecture that makes it possible for generative agents to remember, retrieve, reflect, interact with other agents, and plan through dynamically evolving circumstances. The architecture leverages the powerful prompting capabilities of large language models and supplements those capabilities to support longer-term agent coherence, the ability to manage dynamically-evolving memory, and recursively produce more generations.

- Two evaluations (a controlled evaluation and end-to-end evaluation) that establish causal effects of the importance of components of the architecture, as well as identify breakdowns arising from, e.g., improper memory retrieval.

- Discussion of the opportunities and ethical and societal risks of generative agents in interactive systems. We argue that these agents should be tuned to mitigate the risk of users forming parasocial relationships, logged to mitigate risks stemming from deepfakes and tailored persuasion, and applied in ways that complement rather than replace human stakeholders in design processes.

dense_questions.question: What are some envisioned applications of computational agents that simulate believable human behavior?
dense_questions.answer: Simulations of human behavior could populate virtual spaces and communities, train people in difficult interpersonal situations, test social science theories, power ubiquitous computing applications and social robots, and underpin non-playable game characters.
dense_questions.long_answer: Some of the envisioned applications of computational agents that simulate believable human behavior include populating virtual spaces and communities with realistic social phenomena, training individuals to handle rare yet difficult interpersonal situations, testing social science theories, crafting model human processors for theory and usability testing, powering ubiquitous computing applications and social robots, underpinning non-playable game characters that can navigate complex human relationships in an open world, and enabling emergent social dynamics, such as forming new relationships, diffusing information, and coordinating among multiple agents. These applications highlight the potential utility of computational agents in various domains, from social simulations and training scenarios to gaming environments and virtual worlds.

dense_questions.question: What is the primary challenge in developing fully general agents to ensure long-term coherence?
dense_questions.answer: The primary challenge is managing constantly-growing memories as new interactions, conflicts, and events arise and fade over time, while handling cascading social dynamics that unfold between multiple agents.
dense_questions.long_answer: The primary challenge in developing fully general agents to ensure long-term coherence is the management of constantly-growing memories as new interactions, conflicts, and events arise and fade over time, while handling cascading social dynamics that unfold between multiple agents. Additionally, these agents need to retrieve relevant events and interactions over a long period, reflect on those memories to generalize and draw higher-level inferences, and apply that reasoning to create plans and reactions that both make sense in the moment and in the longer-term arc of the agent's behavior. This requires an architecture that can store, synthesize, and apply relevant memories to generate believable behavior using a large language model, and it involves components such as a memory stream, reflection, and planning. The agents need to be able to draw a wide variety of inferences about themselves, other agents, and their environment, create daily plans that reflect their characteristics and experiences, act out those plans, react, and re-plan when appropriate. The challenge lies in ensuring that the agents are capable of coordinating their actions and behaviors over time to create believable simulacra of individual and emergent group behavior in a realistic and consistent manner.

dense_questions.question: What are the key components of the introduced generative agent architecture?
dense_questions.answer: The key components are the memory stream, reflection, and planning.
dense_questions.long_answer:
The key components of the introduced generative agent architecture are as follows:

1. **Memory Stream**: The architecture includes a long-term memory module that records the agent's experiences in natural language. This memory stream stores a comprehensive list of the agent's experiences and allows for the retrieval of relevant memories using a combination of factors such as relevance, recency, and importance to inform the agent's moment-to-moment behavior.

2. **Reflection**: The architecture incorporates a module for synthesizing memories into higher-level inferences over time. This enables the agent to draw conclusions about itself and others, which in turn guides its behavior. By reflecting on past experiences, the generative agent is able to make higher-level inferences and draw conclusions about itself and others to better guide its behavior.

3. **Planning**: The third main component of the architecture is planning, which translates the conclusions drawn from reflection and the current environment into high-level action plans. These plans are then recursively translated into detailed behaviors for action and reaction. The reflections and plans are fed back into the memory stream to influence the agent's future behavior.

In summary, the introduced architecture of generative agents is designed to enable agents to store, synthesize, and apply relevant memories to generate believable behavior, utilizing a combination of long-term memory storage, reflection on past experiences to draw higher-level inferences, and planning based on those conclusions and current environmental factors.

dense_questions.question: What are the intended applications of the generative agent architecture mentioned in the paper?
dense_questions.answer: The intended applications include role-play, social prototyping, virtual worlds, and games.
dense_questions.long_answer:
The intended applications of the generative agent architecture mentioned in the paper include various domains such as role-play and social prototyping, virtual worlds, and games. 

1. **Role-Play Scenarios**: Users could safely rehearse difficult, conflict-laden conversations in scenarios such as interview preparation.

2. **Social Prototyping**: Designers can prototype dynamic, complex interactions that unfold over time, going beyond temporary personas in social platforms.

3. **Virtual Worlds and Games**: The generative agents could be used to create a small, interactive society of agents inspired by games such as The Sims. They can be connected to a large language model to manifest a small society of agents in a game environment, allowing end users to observe and interact with these agents. For example, in a game environment, a developer could suggest hosting an in-game Valentine's Day party to the agents, who can then spread the word about the party, show up, and even ask each other on dates.

In summary, the intended applications of the generative agent architecture include providing a platform for users to safely rehearse difficult conversations, prototyping dynamic interactions for social platforms, and creating interactive societies in virtual worlds and games.

dense_questions.answer: Two evaluations were conducted: a controlled evaluation to test whether the agents produce believable individual behaviors in isolation, and an end-to-end evaluation to understand their stability and emergent social behaviors by interacting with each other in open-ended ways over two days of game time.
dense_questions.long_answer: Two evaluations were conducted on generative agents. The first evaluation was a controlled evaluation designed to test whether the agents produce believable individual behaviors in isolation. The second evaluation was an end-to-end evaluation where the generative agents interacted with each other in open-ended ways over two days of game time to understand their stability and emergent social behaviors. The controlled evaluation aimed to assess the believability of individual behaviors in isolation, while the end-to-end evaluation focused on understanding the stability and emergent social behaviors of the generative agents. These evaluations aimed to establish the causal effects of the components of the architecture and identify breakdowns arising from issues such as improper memory retrieval.

dense_questions.long_answer:
The contributions provided by this paper are as follows:
1. *Generative agents*: The paper presents the concept of generative agents as believable simulacra of human behavior dynamically conditioned on agents' changing experiences and environment.
2. *A novel architecture*: The paper introduces a novel architecture that enables generative agents to remember, retrieve, reflect, interact with other agents, and plan through dynamically evolving circumstances. This architecture harnesses the powerful prompting capabilities of large language models and supplements those capabilities to support longer-term agent coherence, manage dynamically-evolving memory, and recursively produce more generations.
3. *Two evaluations*: The paper conducts two evaluations (a controlled evaluation and end-to-end evaluation) that establish causal effects of the importance of components of the architecture, as well as identify breakdowns arising from, for example, improper memory retrieval.
4. *Discussion of ethical and societal risks*: The paper discusses the opportunities and ethical and societal risks of generative agents in interactive systems. It argues that these agents should be tuned to mitigate the risk of users forming parasocial relationships, logged to mitigate risks stemming from deepfakes and tailored persuasion, and applied in ways that complement rather than replace human stakeholders in design processes.

It is defined as a long-term memory module that records the agent's experiences in natural language, creating a comprehensive list of memories. The memory stream is responsible for storing, synthesizing, and applying relevant memories to generate believable behavior using a large language model. It combines the elements of relevance, recency, and importance to surface the records needed to inform the moment-to-moment behavior of the agent. This memory module is a critical component of the architecture, allowing the agent to retrieve relevant events and interactions over a long period, reflect on those memories to draw higher-level inferences, and apply that reasoning to create plans and reactions that make sense in both the moment and in the longer-term arc of the agent's behavior.

dense_questions.question: What was the methodological approach used for the technical evaluation of generative agents?
dense_questions.answer: The technical evaluation involved 'interviewing' the agents in natural language to probe their ability to stay in character, remember, plan, react, and reflect accurately.
dense_questions.long_answer:
The methodological approach used for the technical evaluation of generative agents involved leveraging a methodological opportunity to evaluate an agent's knowledge and behavior by "interviewing" it in natural language to probe the agents' ability to stay in character, remember, plan, react, and reflect accurately. This approach aimed to assess the agents' capability to retrieve relevant memories, reflect on those memories to draw higher-level inferences, and apply that reasoning to create plans and reactions that make sense in the moment and in the longer-term arc of the agent's behavior. 

The evaluation involved comparing several ablations that limit agents' access to memory, reflection, and planning, with the goal of identifying the causal effects of the architecture's components. It was observed that each of these components is critical to strong performance across the interview tasks. The evaluations aimed to establish the importance of the components of the architecture and also sought to identify breakdowns arising from issues such as improper memory retrieval.

In essence, the technical evaluation involved a rigorous probing of the generative agents' capabilities and performance through natural language "interviews" to assess their ability to simulate believable human behavior and to identify any breakdowns or errors within the architecture's components.

dense_questions.question: What were observed as critical components for strong performance in the technical and end-to-end evaluations?
dense_questions.answer: The memory, reflection, and planning components were observed as critical for strong performance in both evaluations.
dense_questions.long_answer:
The critical components for strong performance observed in the technical and end-to-end evaluations of generative agents were the memory, reflection, and planning capabilities embedded in the agent architecture. The evaluations demonstrated that each of these components is essential for the generative agents to exhibit believable individual behaviors in isolation and to engage in open-ended interactions with other agents over an extended period.

The *memory stream* module, which serves as a long-term memory for the agents, was identified as a critical component. It records the agents' experiences in natural language, and its retrieval model combines relevance, recency, and importance to surface the records needed to inform the agents' moment-to-moment behavior.

The *reflection* component was also highlighted as crucial. It synthesizes memories into higher-level inferences over time, enabling the agents to draw conclusions about themselves and others, thus guiding their behavior.

Additionally, the *planning* component was found to be critical for strong performance. It translates conclusions drawn from reflections and the current environment into high-level action plans and detailed behaviors for action and reaction. These plans are then recursively fed back into the memory stream to influence the agents' future behavior.

The evaluations concluded that the generative agents' ability to remember, retrieve, reflect, interact with other agents, and plan through dynamically evolving circumstances are key components that lead to strong performance. The findings emphasized the importance of these components in enabling generative agents to simulate believable human behavior dynamically and evolve over time.

dense_questions.answer: The most common errors arose when the agent failed to retrieve relevant memories, fabricated embellishments to the agent's memory, or inherited overly formal speech or behavior from the language model.
dense_questions.long_answer: The most common errors observed across the technical and end-to-end evaluations of generative agents included instances where the agent failed to retrieve relevant memories, fabricated embellishments to the agent's memory, or inherited overly formal speech or behavior from the language model. These errors were critical to the performance of the agents in tasks such as staying in character, remembering, planning, reacting, and reflecting accurately. The study found that each component - memory, reflection, and planning - was critical to the strong performance of the agents across these evaluation tasks. The errors related to memory retrieval and fabricated embellishments indicate the challenge in managing dynamically evolving memory and ensuring that the agents' behaviors and responses are coherent with their past experiences and the current environment. Additionally, the inheritance of overly formal speech or behavior from the language model suggests the need for fine-tuning the language model's outputs to better align with the desired behavior of the generative agents.

sparse_questions.question: What are the main goals of generating believable simulacra of human behavior?
sparse_questions.answer: The main goals of generating believable simulacra of human behavior include populating virtual spaces and communities with realistic social phenomena, training people how to handle rare yet difficult interpersonal situations, testing social science theories, crafting model human processors for theory and usability testing, powering ubiquitous computing applications and social robots, and underpinning non-playable game characters that can navigate complex human relationships in an open world.
sparse_questions.long_answer:
The main goals of generating believable simulacra of human behavior, as outlined in the provided reference, are as follows:

1. Populate virtual spaces and communities with realistic social phenomena: The goal is to create computational agents that can simulate believable human behavior in order to populate virtual spaces with realistic social phenomena.

2. Train people on handling rare yet difficult interpersonal situations: By simulating believable human behavior, these generative agents can be used to train individuals on how to handle rare but challenging interpersonal situations.

3. Test social science theories: The capability to simulate believable human behavior allows for testing social science theories in a virtual environment.

4. Craft model human processors for theory and usability testing: Generative agents can serve as model human processors for theory and usability testing, helping to evaluate and improve various systems and applications.

5. Power ubiquitous computing applications and social robots: Believable simulacra of human behavior can be used to power ubiquitous computing applications and social robots, enhancing their effectiveness and realism.

6. Underpin non-playable game characters: These generative agents can be used to create non-playable game characters that can navigate complex human relationships in an open world, providing a richer gaming experience.

Overall, the main goals of generating believable simulacra of human behavior include creating realistic social simulations, facilitating training and testing, powering computing applications and social robots, and underpinning game characters.

sparse_questions.question: What are the challenges associated with simulating believable human behavior?
sparse_questions.answer: The challenges include the vast and complex space of human behavior, the need for consistently-growing memories to manage constantly-growing interactions, conflicts, and events over time, and the handling of cascading social dynamics that unfold between multiple agents.
sparse_questions.long_answer: The challenges associated with simulating believable human behavior include the vast and complex space of human behavior, the need for long-term coherence in agents' behavior, and the management of constantly growing memories as new interactions, conflicts, and events arise and fade over time. The reference highlights that despite striking progress in large language models that can simulate believable human behavior at a single time point, fully general agents that ensure long-term coherence would require architectures that can handle cascading social dynamics unfolding between multiple agents. Specifically, the challenges include the need for approaches that can retrieve relevant events and interactions over a long period, reflect on those memories to generalize and draw higher-level inferences, and apply that reasoning to create plans and reactions that make sense in both the moment and the longer-term arc of the agent's behavior. The paper emphasizes that success requires architectures capable of synthesizing relevant memories into higher-level inferences over time, enabling the agent to draw conclusions about itself and others to better guide its behavior. Additionally, simulating believable human behavior involves the need to translate conclusions and the current environment into high-level action plans and then recursively into detailed behaviors for action and reaction. Therefore, the challenges encompass the complexities of human behavior, the requirement for long-term coherence, and the management of constantly growing memories while handling dynamically evolving social dynamics between multiple agents.

sparse_questions.question: What are generative agents, and what kind of behaviors do they demonstrate?
sparse_questions.answer: Generative agents draw on generative models to simulate believable human behavior. They create daily plans that reflect their characteristics and experiences, act out those plans, react, and re-plan when appropriate. They can also respond when the end user changes their environment or commands them in natural language.
sparse_questions.long_answer: Generative agents are computationally powered agents that simulate believable human behavior by drawing on generative models. These agents are capable of remembering, retrieving, reflecting, and interacting with other agents, as well as planning through dynamically evolving circumstances. They produce believable simulacra of both individual and emergent group behavior. Generative agents demonstrate a wide variety of behaviors, such as creating daily plans that reflect their characteristics and experiences, acting out those plans, reacting, and re-planning when appropriate. They respond to changes in their environment or commands in natural language, acting in ways that make sense both in the moment and in the longer-term arc of their behavior. Their behaviors include turning off the stove when food is burning, waiting outside the bathroom if it is occupied, and stopping to chat when they meet another agent they want to talk to. In a society populated by generative agents, emergent social dynamics occur, including the formation of new relationships, diffusion of information, and coordination among agents.

sparse_questions.question: What are the three main components of the architecture required to enable generative agents, and what are their roles?
sparse_questions.answer: The three main components of the architecture are the memory stream, reflection, and planning. The memory stream is a long-term memory module that records a comprehensive list of the agent's experiences. Reflection synthesizes memories into higher-level inferences over time, enabling the agent to draw conclusions about itself and others. Planning translates those conclusions and the current environment into high-level action plans and then recursively into detailed behaviors for action and reaction. These reflections and plans are fed back into the memory stream to influence the agent's future behavior.
sparse_questions.long_answer:
The three main components of the architecture required to enable generative agents are the *memory stream*, *reflection*, and *planning*.

1. **Memory Stream**: This component serves as a long-term memory module that records the agent's experiences in natural language. It maintains a comprehensive list of the agent's experiences and interactions. The memory stream is designed to combine relevance, recency, and importance to surface the records that are needed to inform the agent's moment-to-moment behavior. It plays a crucial role in enabling generative agents to retrieve relevant events and interactions over a long period, reflect on those memories to generalize and draw higher-level inferences, and apply that reasoning to create *plans and reactions* that make sense in the moment and in the longer-term arc of the agent's behavior.

2. **Reflection**: The reflection component synthesizes memories into higher-level inferences over time, enabling the agent to draw conclusions about itself and others to better guide its behavior. This component allows the agent to draw a wide variety of inferences about itself, other agents, and the environment, enabling it to create daily plans that reflect its characteristics and experiences. These reflections are then fed back into the memory stream to influence the agent's future behavior.

3. **Planning**: The planning component translates the conclusions drawn from reflection and the current environment into high-level action plans and then recursively into detailed behaviors for action and reaction. It plays a crucial role in enabling the agent to create plans that reflect their characteristics and experiences, act out those plans, react, and re-plan when appropriate. This recursive planning process is essential for ensuring that the agents produce believable simulacra of both individual and emergent group behavior.

These three components work together to enable generative agents to remember, retrieve, reflect, interact with other agents, and plan through dynamically evolving circumstances, thereby simulating believable human behavior.

sparse_questions.question: What applications does the architecture for generative agents suggest in multiple domains?
sparse_questions.answer: The architecture suggests applications in multiple domains, including role-play and social prototyping, virtual worlds and games. It enables scenarios such as interview preparation, safe rehearsals of difficult, conflict-laden conversations, and the prototyping of dynamic, complex interactions that unfold over time.
sparse_questions.long_answer:
The architecture for generative agents suggests applications in multiple domains. These domains include role-play and social prototyping, as well as virtual worlds and games. In social role-play scenarios, such as interview preparation, users could safely rehearse difficult, conflict-laden conversations. When prototyping social platforms, a designer could move beyond temporary personas to prototype dynamic, complex interactions that unfold over time. 

The focus of the paper, however, is on the ability to create a small, interactive society of agents inspired by games such as The Sims. By connecting the architecture to the ChatGPT large language model, the paper manifests a small society of twenty-five agents in a game environment. End users can observe and interact with these agents. For instance, if an end user or developer wanted the town to host an in-game Valentine's Day party, traditional game environments would require scripting tens of characters' behavior manually. However, with generative agents, it is sufficient to simply tell one agent that she wants to throw a party. Despite the potential points of failure, such as making sure other agents remember the invitation and decide to show up, the agents in the environment succeed in spreading the word about the party and showing up, demonstrating the potential applications of generative agents in complex social scenarios within virtual environments and games.

In summary, the architecture for generative agents suggests applications in role-play, social prototyping, virtual worlds, and games, offering the ability to create dynamic, believable social interactions within these domains.

sparse_questions.question: How did the generative agents perform in the two evaluations conducted, and what were the observations?
sparse_questions.answer: In the controlled evaluation, the generative agents were tested for producing believable individual behaviors in isolation, while the end-to-end evaluation involved the agents interacting with each other in open-ended ways over two days of game time. The evaluation showed that the components of the architecture, including memory, reflection, and planning, were critical to the agents' performance. The most common errors arose when the agent failed to retrieve relevant memories, fabricated embellishments to the agent's memory, or inherited overly formal speech or behavior from the language model.
sparse_questions.long_answer:
The generative agents were evaluated in two different scenarios: a controlled evaluation testing their individual behaviors in isolation, and an end-to-end evaluation where they interacted with each other in open-ended ways over two days of game time.

In the controlled evaluation, the agents were tested to assess whether they could produce believable individual behaviors in isolation. The evaluation involved interviewing the agents in natural language to probe their ability to stay in character, remember, plan, react, and reflect accurately. Several ablations were compared, which limited the agents' access to memory, reflection, and planning. The results indicated that each of these components (memory, reflection, and planning) was crucial to the strong performance of the agents across the interview tasks. The most common errors observed were related to the agent's failure to retrieve relevant memories, fabricating embellishments to their memory, or displaying overly formal speech or behavior inherited from the language model.

In the end-to-end evaluation, the generative agents interacted with each other in open-ended ways over two days of game time. The purpose was to understand their stability and emergent social behaviors. The observations from this evaluation demonstrated that the generative agents were successful in creating emergent social dynamics, forming new relationships, diffusing information, and coordinating across the agents. The evaluation also identified breakdowns arising from improper memory retrieval, highlighting the importance of managing dynamically-evolving memory for the long-term coherence and stability of the agents.

These evaluations provided important insights into the performance of generative agents, emphasizing the critical role of memory, reflection, and planning in creating believable and stable behavior.

sparse_questions.question: What are the main contributions of the paper?
sparse_questions.answer: The paper provides generative agents, a novel architecture that enables generative agents to remember, retrieve, reflect, interact with other agents, and plan through dynamically evolving circumstances, and two evaluations that establish causal effects of the importance of components of the architecture. It also discusses the opportunities and ethical and societal risks of generative agents in interactive systems.
sparse_questions.long_answer:
The main contributions of the paper are as follows:
1. **Generative agents**: The paper presents the concept of generative agents, which are believable simulations of human behavior dynamically conditioned on the agents' changing experiences and environment. These agents draw on generative models to simulate realistic human-like behavior and interactions.
2. **Architecture for generative agents**: The paper introduces a novel architecture that enables generative agents to remember, retrieve, reflect, interact with other agents, and plan through dynamically evolving circumstances. This architecture leverages the capabilities of large language models to support longer-term agent coherence and the ability to manage dynamically-evolving memory. It also allows for the recursive production of more generations of behavior.
3. **Evaluations**: The paper includes two evaluations - a controlled evaluation and an end-to-end evaluation - to establish causal effects of the importance of components of the architecture and to identify breakdowns arising from improper memory retrieval. These evaluations provide insights into the performance and behavior of generative agents in various scenarios.
4. **Discussion of ethical and societal risks**: The paper discusses the opportunities and ethical and societal risks of generative agents in interactive systems. It argues for tuning these agents to mitigate the risk of users forming parasocial relationships, logging to mitigate risks stemming from deepfakes and tailored persuasion, and applying them in ways that complement rather than replace human stakeholders in design processes.

These contributions collectively offer a framework for creating interactive artificial societies with generative agents, and they provide insights into the potential applications, challenges, and ethical considerations of implementing such agents in various domains.

## 2 Related Work.text:
## 2 Related Work

In this section, we reflect on the prior literature in human-AI interaction and situate within its canon the agenda of building believable proxies of human behavior. This agenda, once hailed as a north star in interaction, game, and artificial intelligence communities [9, 58, 84, 85], has remained challenging due to the complexity of human behavior [16, 108]. We synthesize this research to suggest that large language models, though not sufficient by themselves, open up a new angle for creating believable agents when leveraged using the appropriate architecture.

## 2.1 Human-Ai Interaction.text:
## 2.1 Human-Ai Interaction

Interactive artificial intelligence systems aim to combine human insights and capabilities in computational artifacts that can augment their users [3, 29]. A long line of work has explored ways to allow users to interactively specify model behavior. For instance, Crayons demonstrated an early vision of interactive machine learning, allowing non-expert users to train classifiers [29]. Further work helped to articulate how end users might describe their classification goals to the system through examples [33] and/or demonstration [31]. More recent work has extended these explorations to deep learning [62] and prompt-based authoring [49, 66, 106].

Meanwhile, a persistent thread of research has advanced the case for language- and agent-based interaction in human-computer interaction. Formative work such as SHRDLU [103] and ELIZA [102] demonstrated the opportunity and the risks of natural language interaction with computing systems. As research progressed, it became clear that autonomous agents could offer new metaphors for delegation and interaction [67], but the delegation lines between humans and agents have continued to be debated and refined [46, 88, 89]. Recently, this technology has become stable enough that it has become possible for agents to interact via natural language in large and complex online social environments (e.g., [54]). Natural language interaction offers a novel modality that can extend user abilities in domains such as photo editing [2, 34, 64] and code editing [87].

We convene these threads of work to show that we can now create agents that proxy human behavior for interactive systems, and interact with them via natural language. In doing so, this work re-opens the door to examining foundational HCI questions around cognitive models such as GOMS and KLM [21, 22], around prototyping tools [79], and around ubiquitous computing applications [25, 30, 100].

## 2.2 Believable Proxies Of Human Behav.text:
## 2.2 Believable Proxies Of Human Behavior

Prior literature has described *believability*, or *believable agents*, as a central design and engineering goal. Believable agents are designed to provide an illusion of life and present a facade of realism in the way they appear to make decisions and act on their own volition, similar to the characters in Disney movies [9, 95]. These agents can populate and perceive an open-world environment like the one we inhabit [9, 58], and strive to behave in ways that exhibit emergent behaviors grounded in social interactions with users or other agents with the aim of becoming believable proxies of our behavior in hypothetical simulations of individuals and communities [19, 35, 70].

Historically, these agents were developed in the context of intelligent game NPCs [58, 84]. Creating NPCs with believable behavior, if possible, could enhance player experiences in games and interactive fictions by enabling emergent narratives [7, 15, 48, 92] and social interactions with the agents [110]. However, more importantly, game worlds provide increasingly realistic representations of real-world affordances, and as observed by Laird and van Lent in 2001, these simulated worlds offer accessible testbeds for developers of believable agents to finesse the agents' cognitive capabilities without worrying about implementing robotics in the real world or creating simulation environments from scratch [58, 84].

A diverse set of approaches to creating believable agents emerged over the past four decades. In implementation, however, these approaches often simplified the environment or dimensions of agent behavior to make the effort more manageable [16, 72]. Rule-based approaches, such as finite-state machines [90, 96] and behavior trees [40, 53, 81], account for the brute force approach of human-authoring the agent's behavior [70]. They provide a straightforward way of creating simple agents that is still the most dominant approach today [68, 73, 109], and can even handle rudimentary social interactions, as shown in simulation games such as Mass Effect [12] and The Sims [6] series. Nonetheless, manually crafting behavior that can comprehensively address the breadth of possible interactions in an open world is untenable. This means that the resulting agent behaviors may not fully represent the consequences of their interactions [69–71], and cannot perform new procedures that were not hard-coded in their script [90, 96].

On the other hand, prevalent learning-based approaches for creating believable agents, such as reinforcement learning, have overcome the challenge of manual authoring by letting the agents learn their behavior, and have achieved superhuman performance in recent years in games such as AlphaStar for Starcraft [98] and OpenAI Five for Dota 2 [10]. However, their success has largely taken place in adversarial games with readily definable rewards that a learning algorithm can optimize for. They have not yet addressed the challenge of creating believable agents in an open world [39, 73, 90].

Cognitive architectures in computation, pioneered by Newell, aimed to build the infrastructure for supporting a comprehensive set of cognitive functions [75] that suited the all-encompassing nature of believable agents held in its original vision. They fueled some of the earliest examples of believable agents. For instance, Quakebot-SOAR [59] and ICARUS [24, 63] generated NPCs in first-person shooter games, while TacAir-SOAR [80] generated pilots in aerial combat training simulations. The architectures used by these agents differed (Quakebot- and TacAir-SOAR relied on SOAR [60], while ICARUS relied on its own variation that was inspired by SOAR and ACT-R [5]), but they shared the same underlying principle [61]. They maintained short-term and long-term memories, filled these memories with symbolic structures, and operated in perceive-plan-act cycles, dynamically perceiving the environment and matching it with one of the manually crafted action procedures [57, 96]. Agents created using cognitive architectures aimed to be generalizable to most, if not all, open-world contexts and exhibited robust behavior for their time. However, their space of action was limited to manually crafted procedural knowledge, and they did not offer a mechanism through which the agents could be inspired to seek new behavior. As such, these agents were deployed mostly in non-open-world contexts such as first-person shooter games [24, 59] or blocks worlds [63].

Today, creating believable agents as described in its original definition remains an open problem [84, 108]. Many have moved on, arguing that although existing approaches for creating believable agents might be cumbersome and limited, they are good enough to support existing gameplay and interactions [23, 74, 108]. Our argument is that large language models offer an opportunity to re-examine these questions, provided that we can craft an effective architecture to synthesize memories into believable behavior. We offer a step toward such an architecture in this paper.

dense_questions.long_answer: Believable agents are designed to provide an illusion of life and present a facade of realism in the way they appear to make decisions and act on their own volition, similar to the characters in Disney movies. These agents can populate and perceive an open-world environment and strive to behave in ways that exhibit emergent behaviors grounded in social interactions with users or other agents with the aim of becoming believable proxies of human behavior in hypothetical simulations of individuals and communities. The design and engineering goal is to create agents that offer a realistic representation of real-world affordances and can interact with users or other agents in a way that enhances player experiences in games and interactive fictions. Ultimately, the goal is to create agents that exhibit behavior that is comprehensive, realistic, and believable within an open-world context.

dense_questions.question: What is the historical context in which believable agents were developed?
dense_questions.answer: Historically, these agents were developed in the context of intelligent game NPCs.
dense_questions.long_answer: Believable agents were historically developed in the context of intelligent game Non-Player Characters (NPCs). These NPCs were designed to exhibit believable behavior and enhance player experiences in games and interactive fictions by enabling emergent narratives and social interactions. The simulated game worlds provided accessible testbeds for developers to finesse the agents' cognitive capabilities without worrying about implementing robotics in the real world or creating simulation environments from scratch. The goal was to create agents that exhibit emergent behaviors grounded in social interactions with users or other agents with the aim of becoming believable proxies of human behavior in hypothetical simulations of individuals and communities. The historical development of believable agents has encompassed a diverse set of approaches over the past four decades, including rule-based approaches, learning-based approaches, and cognitive architectures in computation. Despite the advancements in creating believable agents, the challenge of creating such agents in an open world context remains an open problem.

dense_questions.question: What are some examples of the prevalent rule-based approaches to creating believable agents?
dense_questions.answer: Examples of prevalent rule-based approaches include finite-state machines and behavior trees.
dense_questions.long_answer: According to the provided reference, some prevalent rule-based approaches to creating believable agents include finite-state machines and behavior trees. These approaches involve human-authoring the agent's behavior and provide a straightforward way of creating simple agents. Finite-state machines and behavior trees are still the most dominant approach today and can even handle rudimentary social interactions, as demonstrated in simulation games such as Mass Effect and The Sims series. However, manually crafting behavior to comprehensively address the breadth of possible interactions in an open world using these rule-based approaches is considered untenable.

dense_questions.question: What are the challenges associated with rule-based approaches for creating believable agents?
dense_questions.answer: Rule-based approaches may not fully represent the consequences of interactions, and resulting agent behaviors may not perform new procedures that were not hard-coded in their script.
dense_questions.long_answer:
The challenges associated with rule-based approaches for creating believable agents primarily stem from the limitations in comprehensively addressing the breadth of possible interactions in an open world. The reference mentions that rule-based approaches, such as finite-state machines and behavior trees, require human-authoring of the agent's behavior, which results in a brute force approach. These approaches provide a straightforward way of creating simple agents and are still the most dominant approach today. However, manually crafting behavior that can comprehensively address the breadth of possible interactions in an open world is untenable. This means that the resulting agent behaviors may not fully represent the consequences of their interactions and cannot perform new procedures that were not hard-coded in their script.

In summary, the challenges of rule-based approaches for creating believable agents include the limited capacity to address the full range of interactions in an open world, the inability to fully represent the consequences of agent interactions, and the incapability to perform new procedures that were not hard-coded in their script.

sparse_questions.question: What is the concept of cognitive architectures in creating believable agents?
sparse_questions.answer: Cognitive architectures, pioneered by Newell, aimed to build the infrastructure for supporting a comprehensive set of cognitive functions that suited the all-encompassing nature of believable agents held in its original vision. It fueled some of the earliest examples of believable agents.
sparse_questions.long_answer:
The concept of cognitive architectures in creating believable agents refers to the use of computational frameworks that aim to emulate a comprehensive set of cognitive functions in agents, enabling them to exhibit complex and adaptive behaviors. These architectures, pioneered by Newell, are designed to support the development of agents that can perceive, plan, and act dynamically in their environment, much like humans do. The architecture maintains short-term and long-term memories, utilizes symbolic structures, and operates through perceive-plan-act cycles.

Historically, cognitive architectures have been utilized in the development of believable agents such as Quakebot-SOAR, ICARUS, and TacAir-SOAR, which were deployed in first-person shooter games and aerial combat training simulations. These architectures were intended to provide a basis for agents to operate in open-world contexts and exhibit robust, adaptive behavior. However, they primarily relied on manually crafted procedural knowledge and did not provide mechanisms for agents to seek new behavior. As a result, the space of action for these agents was limited to the behavior hard-coded in their scripts.

In summary, cognitive architectures in creating believable agents aim to provide a foundation for agents to exhibit advanced cognitive functions, perceive and interact with their environment, and produce behavior that is adaptable and realistic. However, the existing cognitive architectures have limitations in their ability to generate novel behavior and operate effectively in open-world contexts.

sparse_questions.question: What are the limitations associated with agents created using cognitive architectures?
sparse_questions.answer: The limitations associated with agents created using cognitive architectures include their space of action being limited to manually crafted procedural knowledge, and the absence of a mechanism through which the agents could be inspired to seek new behavior.
sparse_questions.long_answer:
The limitations associated with agents created using cognitive architectures include the following:

1. **Limited Space of Action**: Agents created using cognitive architectures were limited to manually crafted procedural knowledge, constraining their range of possible actions. This limitation restricted their applicability to non-open-world contexts, such as first-person shooter games or block worlds.

2. **Lack of Mechanism for Seeking New Behavior**: These agents did not offer a mechanism through which they could be inspired to seek new behavior. This meant that they were confined to pre-defined actions and did not have the capability to adapt and evolve their behavior based on new experiences or changing environments.

3. **Non-Open-World Contexts**: While these agents exhibited robust behavior within specific contexts, their ability to operate in open-world environments was limited. They were primarily designed for specific scenarios and lacked the adaptability required to function effectively in diverse, open-world settings.

These limitations highlight the challenges associated with cognitive architectures in creating believable agents that can dynamically respond to complex, open-world environments with emergent behaviors.

## 2.3 Large Language Models And Human B.text:
## 2.3 Large Language Models And Human Behavior

Generative agents leverage a large language model to power their behavior. The key observation is that large language models encode a wide range of human behavior represented in their training data [14, 17]. If prompted with a narrowly defined context, the models can be used to generate believable behavior. Recent work has demonstrated the efficacy of this approach. For instance, Social Simulacra used a large language model to generate users that would populate new social computing systems to prototype their emergent social dynamics [79]. This approach used a prompt chain [105, 106] to generate short natural language descriptions of personas and their behaviors as they appear in the system being prototyped. Other empirical studies have replicated existing social science studies [45], political surveys [91], and generated synthetic data [38].

Large language models have also been used to generate interactive human behavior for users to engage with. In gaming, for instance, these models have been employed to create interactive fiction [36] and text adventure games [20]. With their ability to generate and decompose action sequences, large language models have also been used in planning robotics tasks [47]. For example, when presented with a task, such as picking up a bottle, the model is prompted to break down the task into smaller action sequences, such as heading to the table where the bottle is located and picking it up.

We posit that, based on the work summarized above, large language models can become a key ingredient for creating believable agents. The existing literature largely relies on what could be considered first-order templates that employ few-shot prompts [37, 65] or chain-of-thought prompts [99]. These templates are effective in generating behavior that is conditioned solely on the agent's current environment (e.g., how would a troll respond to a given post, what actions would a robot need to take to enter a room given that there is a door). However, believable agents require conditioning not only on their current environment but also on a vast amount of past experience, which is a poor fit (and as of today, impossible due to the underlying models' limited context window) using first-order prompting. Recent studies have attempted to go beyond first-order prompting by augmenting language models with a static knowledge base and an information retrieval scheme [52] or with a simple summarization scheme [104]. This paper extends these ideas to craft an agent architecture that handles retrieval where past experience is dynamically updated at each time step and mixed with agents' current context and plans, which may either reinforce or contradict each other.

It highlights the need to go beyond first-order prompting and proposes the augmentation of language models with a static knowledge base and an information retrieval scheme, or a simple summarization scheme to address this challenge.

In summary, the challenges in conditioning believable agents, as outlined in the document, include the limitations of existing methods in effectively incorporating a rich history of past experiences and the inability to condition agents on a vast amount of past experience due to the limited context window of the underlying language models. The paper proposes the augmentation of language models with knowledge bases, information retrieval schemes, or summarization schemes to address these challenges.

## 3 Generative Agent Behavior And Inter.text:
## 3 Generative Agent Behavior And Interaction

To make concrete the affordances of generative agents, we instantiate them as characters in a simple sandbox world reminiscent of The Sims [6]. This sprite-based sandbox game world, Smallville, evokes a small town environment. In this section, we walk through the affordances and interactions with generative agents in Smallville, and describe how the agents behave in it. Then, in Section 4, we introduce our generative agent architecture that powers these affordances and interactions. In Section 5, we describe the sandbox environment implementation and how the agents interact with the sandbox world's underlying engine.

## 3.1 Agent Avatar And Communication.text:
## 3.1 Agent Avatar And Communication

A community of 25 unique agents inhabit Smallville. Each agent is represented by a simple sprite avatar. We authored one paragraph of natural language description to depict each agent's identity, including their occupation and relationship with other agents, as seed memories. For example, John Lin has the following description:

John Lin is a pharmacy shopkeeper at the Willow Market and Pharmacy who loves to help people. He is always looking for ways to make the process of getting medication easier for his customers; John Lin is living with his wife, Mei Lin, who is a college professor, and son, Eddy Lin, who is a student studying music theory; John Lin loves his family very much; John Lin has known the old couple next-door, Sam Moore and Jennifer Moore, for a few years; John Lin thinks Sam Moore is a kind and nice man; John Lin knows his neighbor, Yuriko Yamamoto, well; John Lin knows of his neighbors, Tamara Taylor and Carmen Ortiz, but has not met them before; John Lin and Tom Moreno are colleagues at The Willows Market and Pharmacy; John Lin and Tom Moreno are friends and like to discuss local politics together; John Lin knows the Moreno family somewhat well - the husband Tom Moreno and the wife Jane Moreno.

Each semicolon-delimited phrase is entered into the agent's initial memory as memories at the start of the simulation.

### 3.1.1 Inter-Agent Communication

The agents interact with the world by their actions, and with each other through natural language. At each time step of the sandbox engine, the agents output a natural language statement describing their current action, such as "Isabella Rodriguez is writing in her journal", "Isabella Rodriguez is checking her emails", "Isabella Rodriguez is talking with her family on the phone", or "Isabella Rodriguez is getting ready for bed". This statement is then translated into concrete movements that affect the sandbox world. The action is displayed on the sandbox interface as a set of emojis that provide an abstract representation of the action in the overhead view. To accomplish this, the system employs a language model that translates the action into a set of emojis, which appear above each avatar in a speech bubble. For example, "Isabella Rodriguez is writing in her journal" is displayed as 📝, while "Isabella Rodriguez is checking her emails" appears as 📧. The full natural language description of the action can be accessed by clicking on the agent avatar.

Agents communicate with each other in full natural language. Agents are aware of other agents in their local area, and the generative agent architecture determines whether they walk by or engage in conversation. Here, a sample in the middle of a conversation between the agents Isabella Rodriguez and Tom Moreno about the upcoming election:

Isabella: I'm still weighing my options, but I've been discussing the election with Sam Moore. What are your thoughts on him?
Tom: To be honest, I don't like Sam Moore. I think he's out of touch with the community and doesn't have our best interests at heart.

### 3.1.2 User Controls

A user running this simulation can steer the simulation and intervene, either by communicating with the agent through conversation, or by issuing a directive to an agent in the form of an 'inner voice'.

The user communicates with the agent through natural language, by specifying a persona that the agent should perceive them as. For example, if the user specifies that they are a news "reporter" and asks about the upcoming election, "Who is running for office?", the John agent replies:

John: My friends Yuriko, Tom and I have been talking about the upcoming election and discussing the candidate Sam Moore. We have all agreed to vote for him because we like his platform.

To directly command one of the agents, the user takes on the persona of the agent's "inner voice"—this makes the agent more likely to treat the statement as a directive. For instance, when told "You are going to run against Sam in the upcoming election" by a user as John's inner voice, John decides to run in the election and shares his candidacy with his wife and son.

## 3.2 Environmental Interaction.text:
## 3.2 Environmental Interaction

Smallville features the common affordances of a small village including a cafe, bar, park, school, dorm, houses, and stores. It also defines subareas and objects that make those spaces functional, such as a kitchen in a house and a stove in the kitchen (Figure 2).

All spaces serving as agents' primary living quarters feature a bed, desk, closet, shelf, as well as a bathroom and a kitchen. Agents move around Smallville as one would in a simple video game, entering and leaving buildings, navigating its map, and approaching other agents. Agent movements are directed by the generative agent architecture and the sandbox game engine: when the model dictates that the agent will move to a location, we calculate a walking path to the destination in the Smallville environment and the agent begins moving. 

In addition, users can also enter the sandbox world of Smallville as an agent operating within it. The agent that the user embodies can be an agent already present in the world, such as Isabella and John, or it can be an outside visitor with no prior history in Smallville. The inhabitants of Smallville will treat the user-controlled agent no differently than they treat each other. They recognize its presence, initiate interactions, and remember its behavior before forming opinions about it.

Users and agents can influence the state of the objects in this world, much like in sandbox games such as The Sims. For example, a bed can be occupied when an agent is sleeping, and a refrigerator can be empty when an agent uses up the ingredients to make breakfast. End users can also reshape an agent's environment in Smallville by rewriting the status of objects surrounding the agent in natural language. For instance, when Isabella is making breakfast in the morning, the user can change the status of the kitchen stove from "turned on" to "burning" by inputting a command to the system that chooses the object and illustrates its new status, like this: "<Isabella's apartment: kitchen: stove> is burning." Isabella will notice this in the next moment and go to turn off the stove and remake her breakfast. Likewise, if the user sets the status of Isabella's shower to "leaking water" when she enters the bathroom, she gathers tools from her living room and try to fix the leak.

*This environment design is not the focus of our work, so we generate this environment manually, not automatically. Future work can continue to expand the richness of the agents' environments.*

## 3.3 Example \"Day In The Life\".text:
## 3.3 Example "Day In The Life"

Starting from the single-paragraph description, agents begin to plan their days. As time passes in the sandbox world, their behaviors evolve as these agents interact with each other and the world, build memories and relationships, and coordinate joint activities.

We demonstrate the behavior of generative agents by tracing the output of our system over the course of one day for the agent John Lin (Figure 3). In the Lin family, John is the first to wake up at 7 a.m. He brushes his teeth, takes a shower, gets dressed, eats breakfast, and checks the news at the dining table in the living room. 

At 8 a.m., Eddy follows suit, rushing out of bed to prepare for his classes. He catches up with John just as he is about to head out:

John: Good morning Eddy. Did you sleep well?
Eddy: Good morning dad. Yeah, I slept great.
John: That's good. What are you working on today?
Eddy: I'm working on a new music composition for my class. It's due this week, so I'm trying to get it finished. But I'm having so much fun with it!
John: That sounds great!

Soon after Eddy heads out, Mei wakes up and joins John. Mei asks about her son, and John recalls the conversation that they just had:

Mei: Did Eddy already leave for school?
John: Yes, he just left. He's working on a music composition for his class.
Mei: Oh, that's wonderful! Tell me about it.
John: I think he's really enjoying it! He said he's having a lot of fun with it.
Mei: That's great! I'm so proud of him.

As they finish their conversation, Mei and John pack up. Mei goes on to teach and work on her research paper, while John opens his pharmacy counter at the Willow Market and Pharmacy by 9 a.m.

## 3.4 Emergent Social Behaviors.text:
## 3.4 Emergent Social Behaviors

By interacting with each other, generative agents in Smallville exchange information, form new relationships, and coordinate joint activities. Extending prior work [79], these social behaviors are emergent rather than pre-programmed.

3.4.1 Information Diffusion

As agents notice each other, they may engage in dialogue—as they do so, information can spread from agent to agent. For instance, in a conversation between Sam and Tom at the grocery store, Sam tells Tom about his candidacy in the local election:

Sam: Hey Tom, how's it going?
Tom: Good, thanks. What's up?
Sam: Well, I wanted to talk to you about something. I'm actually running for mayor in the upcoming local election.
Tom: Really? That's great news! Why are you running?
Sam: I've been involved in local politics for years now, and I really feel like I can make a difference in our community. Plus, I want to bring new ideas and perspectives to the table.

Later that day, after Sam left, Tom and John, who heard the news from another source, discuss Sam's chances of winning the election:

John: I heard that Sam Moore is running for mayor in the local election. Do you think he has a good chance of winning?
Tom: I do think he has a good chance. He's been working hard in the community and I think he will get a lot of support. What do you think?
John: I think it's great that he's running. I'm curious to see who else is running and how the election will turn out.

Gradually, Sam's candidacy becomes the talk of the town, with some supporting him and others remaining undecided.

3.4.2 Relationship Memory

Agents in Smallville form new relationships over time, and remember their interactions with other agents. For example, Sam does not know Latoya Williams at the start. While taking a walk in Johnson Park, Sam runs into Latoya, and they introduce themselves and Latoya mentions that she is working on a photography project: "I'm here to take some photos for a project I'm working on." In a later interaction, Sam's interactions with Latoya indicate a memory of that interaction, as he asks "Hi, Latoya. How is your project going?" and she replies "Hi, Sam. It's going well!"

3.4.3 Coordination

Generative agents coordinate with each other. Isabella Rodriguez, at Hobbs Cafe, is initialized with an intent to plan a Valentine's Day party from 5 to 7 p.m. on February 14th. From this seed, the agent proceeds to invite friends and customers when she sees them at Hobbs Cafe or elsewhere. Isabella then spends the afternoon of the 13th decorating the cafe for the occasion. Maria, a frequent customer and close friend of Isabella's, arrives at the cafe. Isabella asks for Maria's help in decorating for the party, and Maria agrees. Maria's character description mentions that she has a crush on Klaus. That night, Maria invites Klaus, her secret crush, to join her at the party, and he gladly accepts.

On Valentine's Day, five agents—including Klaus and Maria—show up at Hobbs Cafe at 5pm and they enjoy the festivities (Figure 4). In this scenario, the end user only set Isabella's initial intent to throw a party and Maria's crush on Klaus: the social behaviors of spreading the word, decorating, asking each other out, arriving at the party, and interacting with each other at the party, were initiated by the agent architecture.

## 4 Generative Agent Architecture.text:
## 4 Generative Agent Architecture

Generative agents aim to provide a framework for behavior in an open world: one that can engage in interactions with other agents and can react to changes in the environment. Generative agents take their current environment and past experience as input and generate behavior as output. Underlying this behavior is a novel agent architecture that combines a large language model with mechanisms for synthesizing and retrieving relevant information to condition the language model's output on. Without these mechanisms, large language models can output behavior, but the resulting agents may not react based on the agent's past experiences, may not make important inferences, and may not maintain long-term coherence. Challenges with long-term planning and coherence remain [18] even with today's most performant models such as GPT-4. Because generative agents produce large streams of events and memories that must be retained, a core challenge of our architecture is to ensure that the most relevant pieces of the agent's memory are retrieved and synthesized when needed.

At the center of our architecture is the memory stream, a database that maintains a comprehensive record of an agent's experience. From the memory stream, records are retrieved as relevant to plan the agent's actions and react appropriately to the environment, and records are recursively synthesized into higher- and higher-level observations that guide behavior. Everything in the architecture is recorded and reasoned over as natural language description, allowing the architecture to leverage a large language model.

Our current implementation utilizes gpt3.5-turbo version of Chat-GPT [76]. We expect that the architectural basics of generative agents—memory, planning, and reflection—will likely remain the same as language models improve. Newer language models (e.g., GPT-4) will continue to expand the expressivity and performance of the prompts that underpin generative agents. As of writing, however, GPT-4's API is still invitation-only, so our agents use ChatGPT.

dense_questions.long_answer:
According to the provided reference "4 Generative Agent Architecture," the core components of the generative agent architecture include:

1. Memory Stream: At the center of the architecture is the memory stream, which functions as a database maintaining a comprehensive record of the agent's experiences. This memory stream is crucial for retrieving relevant records to plan the agent's actions and react appropriately to the environment. Records are also recursively synthesized into higher- and higher-level observations that guide behavior.

2. Large Language Model: The architecture combines a large language model with mechanisms for synthesizing and retrieving relevant information. This large language model takes the current environment and past experiences as input and generates behavior as output. It is noted that using large language models on their own may not result in agents that react based on past experiences, make important inferences, and maintain long-term coherence. Therefore, mechanisms for retrieving and synthesizing relevant information are essential.

3. Mechanisms for Synthesizing and Retrieving Information: These mechanisms are crucial for conditioning the language model's output on synthesized and retrieved information. They ensure that the resulting agents react based on past experiences, make important inferences, and maintain long-term coherence. Without these mechanisms, challenges with long-term planning and coherence may persist, even with today's most performant models such as GPT-4.

In summary, the core components of the generative agent architecture consist of the memory stream, the large language model, and mechanisms for synthesizing and retrieving relevant information. These components are essential for generating behavior in an open world, allowing the agent to engage in interactions with other agents and react to changes in the environment.
